newsitem.title: USA: Spyglass sees Q2 results similar to Q1.
newsitem.headline: Spyglass sees Q2 results similar to Q1.

text.p: Spyglass Inc said Wednesday it expects second quarter expenses and revenues, excluding those due from Microsoft Corp, to be close to those of the first quarter.

"We would expect Q2 to look very similar for us, this is obviously excluding the Microsoft arrangement...in terms of revenue and expense levels," Gary Vilchick, chief financial officer, told analysts in a telephone conference call.
"That's the guidance I would want to give you at this point," he said.
The Spyglass second quarter began January 1.
Spyglass today reported a loss for the first quarter of $0.12 a share. Revenues were $3.89 million, and operating expenses were $6.36 million.
Spyglass said it had agreed with Microsoft for a full buyout of royalties owed to Spyglass for its Mosaic browser technology in Microsoft's Internet Explorer.
The buyout includes a one-time $8 million payment, including $7.5 million in cash. Spyglass said it will recognize the funds in its fiscal second quarter.

Spyglass, which provides embedded software, is in the midst of a product transition to what has been dubbed the device market. The company develops software to link everyday products like cellular phones and televisions to the Internet.

The company has a long list of customers who have agreed to use Spyglass's software and services, which will lead to multiple revenue streams, and claims a significant time-to-market advantage. But, Spyglass expects it will take another few quarters before it sees the real impact in its results.

"We are still seeing 6- to 12-month lead times between when we form a relationship with the company and when we see deployment of those products," said Doug Colbeth, president and chief executive officer of Spyglass.
"While we think this market is very real, we think the major deployments, which is where we would see the major run-time royalties...is a late 1997, (early) '98 type of phenomenon," he said.
Vilchick said at that point he would expect the company to return to "historical" profitability.
In addition to investing in the device market, Spyglass said it is continuing to increase the size of its professional services group.
The group, which customizes and integrates Spyglass' technology into customer's products, totalled 25 at the end of December. It was half that size in October, the company said.
Colbeth said a typical initial software agreement means $200,000 to $250,000 in revenues for Spyglass and in about half of the initial transactions customers ask for professional services.
"Professional services can actually equal the size of the initial transaction," Colbeth said.
